name: Hermann Kober
content:
Hermann Kober (born 1888 in Beuthen,  Germany (now Bytom, Poland), died 4 October 1973 in Birmingham, England) was a Jewish-German mathematician who introduced Erdélyi–Kober operators.
He taught (mathematics and science), up to the early 1960s, at some of the King Edward VI Foundation schools in Birmingham.[1]
 
 
 This article about a German mathematician is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
tags: People from the Province of Silesia
raw:
Mathematician
Hermann Kober (born 1888 in Beuthen,  Germany (now Bytom, Poland), died 4 October 1973 in Birmingham, England) was a Jewish-German mathematician who introduced Erdélyi–Kober operators.
He taught (mathematics and science), up to the early 1960s, at some of the King Edward VI Foundation schools in Birmingham.[1]

References[edit]

^ O'Connor, John J.; Robertson, Edmund F., "Hermann Kober", MacTutor History of Mathematics archive, University of St Andrews.
